segment.source: UE-V 1.0 Security Considerations
segment.target: UE-V 1.0 Security Considerations

segment.source: UE-V 1.0 Security Considerations
segment.target: UE-V 1.0 Security Considerations

segment.source: UE-V 1.0 Security Considerations
segment.target: UE-V 1.0 Security Considerations

segment.source: This topic contains a brief overview of accounts and groups, log files, and other security-related considerations for Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V).
segment.target: This topic contains a brief overview of accounts and groups, log files, and other security-related considerations for Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V).

segment.source: For more information, follow the links that are provided here.
segment.target: For more information, follow the links that are provided here.

segment.source: Security considerations for UE-V configuration
segment.target: Security considerations for UE-V configuration

segment.source: When you create the settings storage share, limit the share access to users that need access.
segment.target: When you create the settings storage share, limit the share access to users that need access.

segment.source: Because settings packages may contain personal information, you should take care to protect them as well as possible.
segment.target: Because settings packages may contain personal information, you should take care to protect them as well as possible.

segment.source: In general, do the following:
segment.target: In general, do the following:

segment.source: Restrict the share to only the users that need access.
segment.target: Restrict the share to only the users that need access.

segment.source: Create a security group for users that have redirected folders on a particular share, and limit access to only those users.
segment.target: Create a security group for users that have redirected folders on a particular share, and limit access to only those users.

segment.source: When you create the share, hide the share by putting a $ after the share name.
segment.target: When you create the share, hide the share by putting a $ after the share name.

segment.source: This will hide the share from casual browsers, and the share will not be visible in My Network Places.
segment.target: This will hide the share from casual browsers, and the share will not be visible in My Network Places.

segment.source: Only give users the minimum amount of permissions needed.
segment.target: Only give users the minimum amount of permissions needed.

segment.source: The permissions needed are shown in the tables below.
segment.target: The permissions needed are shown in the tables below.

segment.source: Set the following share-level (SMB) permissions for the setting storage location folder:
segment.target: Set the following share-level (SMB) permissions for the setting storage location folder:

segment.target: User account

segment.target: Recommended permissions

segment.source: Everyone
segment.target: Everyone

segment.target: No Permissions

segment.target: Security group of UE-V

segment.source: Full Control
segment.target: Full Control

segment.target: Security group of UE-V users

segment.source: This Folder, Subfolders and Files
segment.target: This Folder, Subfolders and Files

segment.source: Use Windows Server 2003 or later servers to host redirected file shares
segment.target: Use Windows Server 2003 or later servers to host redirected file shares

segment.source: User settings package files contain personal information that is transferred between the client computer and the server that stores the settings packages.
segment.target: User settings package files contain personal information that is transferred between the client computer and the server that stores the settings packages.

segment.source: Because of this, you should ensure that the data is protected while it travels over the network.
segment.target: Because of this, you should ensure that the data is protected while it travels over the network.

segment.source: User settings data is vulnerable to these potential threats: interception of the data as it passes over the network; tampering with the data as it passes over the network; and spoofing of the server that hosts the data.
segment.target: User settings data is vulnerable to these potential threats: interception of the data as it passes over the network; tampering with the data as it passes over the network; and spoofing of the server that hosts the data.

segment.source: Several features of Windows Server 2003 and above can help to secure user data:
segment.target: Several features of Windows Server 2003 and above can help to secure user data:

segment.source: Kerberos - Kerberos is standard on all versions of Windows 2000 and Windows Server 2003 and later.
segment.target: Kerberos - Kerberos is standard on all versions of Windows 2000 and Windows Server 2003 and later.

segment.source: Kerberos ensures the highest level of security to network resources.
segment.target: Kerberos ensures the highest level of security to network resources.

segment.source: NTLM authenticates the client only; Kerberos authenticates the server and the client.
segment.target: NTLM authenticates the client only; Kerberos authenticates the server and the client.

segment.source: When NTLM is used, the client does not know whether the server is valid.
segment.target: When NTLM is used, the client does not know whether the server is valid.

segment.source: This is particularly important if the client is exchanging personal files with the server, as is the case with Roaming Profiles.
segment.target: This is particularly important if the client is exchanging personal files with the server, as is the case with Roaming Profiles.

segment.source: Kerberos provides better security than NTLM.
segment.target: Kerberos provides better security than NTLM.

segment.source: Kerberos is not available on Windows NT version 4.0 or earlier operating systems.
segment.target: Kerberos is not available on Windows NT version 4.0 or earlier operating systems.

segment.source: IPsec - The IP Security Protocol (IPsec) provides network-level authentication, data integrity, and encryption.
segment.target: IPsec - The IP Security Protocol (IPsec) provides network-level authentication, data integrity, and encryption.

segment.source: IPsec ensures the following:
segment.target: IPsec ensures the following:

segment.source: Roamed data is safe from data modification while en route.
segment.target: Roamed data is safe from data modification while en route.

segment.source: Roamed data is safe from interception, viewing, or copying.
segment.target: Roamed data is safe from interception, viewing, or copying.

segment.source: Roamed data is safe from being accessed by unauthenticated parties.
segment.target: Roamed data is safe from being accessed by unauthenticated parties.

segment.source: SMB Signing - The Server Message Block (SMB) authentication protocol supports message authentication which prevents active message and "man-in-the-middle" attacks.
segment.target: SMB Signing - The Server Message Block (SMB) authentication protocol supports message authentication which prevents active message and "man-in-the-middle" attacks.

segment.source: SMB signing provides this authentication by placing a digital signature into each SMB.
segment.target: SMB signing provides this authentication by placing a digital signature into each SMB.

segment.source: The digital signature is then verified by both the client and the server.
segment.target: The digital signature is then verified by both the client and the server.

segment.source: In order to use SMB signing, you must first either enable it or require it on both the SMB client and the SMB server.
segment.target: In order to use SMB signing, you must first either enable it or require it on both the SMB client and the SMB server.

segment.source: Note that the SMB signing imposes a performance penalty.
segment.target: Note that the SMB signing imposes a performance penalty.

segment.source: It does not consume any more network bandwidth, but it uses more CPU cycles on the client and server side.
segment.target: It does not consume any more network bandwidth, but it uses more CPU cycles on the client and server side.

segment.source: Always use the NTFS File system for volumes holding users data
segment.target: Always use the NTFS File system for volumes holding users data

segment.source: For the most secure configuration, configure servers that host the UE-V settings files to use the NTFS File System.
segment.target: For the most secure configuration, configure servers that host the UE-V settings files to use the NTFS File System.

segment.source: Unlike FAT, NTFS supports Discretionary access control lists (DACLs) and system access control lists (SACLs).
segment.target: Unlike FAT, NTFS supports Discretionary access control lists (DACLs) and system access control lists (SACLs).

segment.source: DACLs and SACLs control who can perform operations on a file and what events will trigger the logging of actions performed on a file.
segment.target: DACLs and SACLs control who can perform operations on a file and what events will trigger the logging of actions performed on a file.

segment.source: Do not rely on EFS to encrypt users’ files when transmitted over the network
segment.target: Do not rely on EFS to encrypt users’ files when transmitted over the network

segment.source: When you use Encrypting File System (EFS) to encrypt files on a remote server, the encrypted data is not encrypted during transit over the network; It only becomes encrypted when stored on disk.
segment.target: When you use Encrypting File System (EFS) to encrypt files on a remote server, the encrypted data is not encrypted during transit over the network; It only becomes encrypted when stored on disk.

segment.source: The exceptions to this are when your system includes Internet Protocol security (IPsec) or Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning (WebDAV).
segment.target: The exceptions to this are when your system includes Internet Protocol security (IPsec) or Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning (WebDAV).

segment.source: IPsec encrypts data while it is transported over a TCP/IP network.
segment.target: IPsec encrypts data while it is transported over a TCP/IP network.

segment.source: If the file is encrypted before being copied or moved to a WebDAV folder on a server, it will remain encrypted during the transmission and while it is stored on the server.
segment.target: If the file is encrypted before being copied or moved to a WebDAV folder on a server, it will remain encrypted during the transmission and while it is stored on the server.

segment.source: Encrypt the Offline Files cache
segment.target: Encrypt the Offline Files cache

segment.source: By default, the Offline Files cache is protected on NTFS partitions by ACLs, but encrypting the cache further enhances security on a local computer.
segment.target: By default, the Offline Files cache is protected on NTFS partitions by ACLs, but encrypting the cache further enhances security on a local computer.

segment.source: By default, the cache on the local computer is not encrypted, so any encrypted files cached from the network will not be encrypted on the local computer.
segment.target: By default, the cache on the local computer is not encrypted, so any encrypted files cached from the network will not be encrypted on the local computer.

segment.source: This may pose a security risk in some environments.
segment.target: This may pose a security risk in some environments.

segment.source: When encryption is enabled, all files in the Offline Files cache are encrypted.
segment.target: When encryption is enabled, all files in the Offline Files cache are encrypted.

segment.source: This includes encrypting existing files as well as files that are added later.
segment.target: This includes encrypting existing files as well as files that are added later.

segment.source: The cached copy on the local computer is affected, but the associated network copy is not.
segment.target: The cached copy on the local computer is affected, but the associated network copy is not.

segment.source: The cache can be encrypted in one of two ways:
segment.target: The cache can be encrypted in one of two ways:

segment.source: Via Group Policy.
segment.target: Via Group Policy.

segment.source: - Enable the Encrypt the Offline Files Cache setting, located at Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesNetworkOffline Files, in the Group Policy editor.
segment.target: - Enable the Encrypt the Offline Files Cache setting, located at Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesNetworkOffline Files, in the Group Policy editor.

segment.source: Manually.
segment.target: Manually.

segment.source: - Select Tools and then Folder Options in the command menu of Windows Explorer.
segment.target: - Select Tools and then Folder Options in the command menu of Windows Explorer.

segment.source: Select the Offline Files tab, and then select the Encrypt offline files to secure data check box.
segment.target: Select the Offline Files tab, and then select the Encrypt offline files to secure data check box.

segment.source: Let the UE-V Agent create folders for each user
segment.target: Let the UE-V Agent create folders for each user

segment.source: To ensure that UE-V works optimally, create only the root share on the server, and let the UE-V Agent create the folders for each user.
segment.target: To ensure that UE-V works optimally, create only the root share on the server, and let the UE-V Agent create the folders for each user.

segment.source: UE-V will create these user folders with the appropriate security.
segment.target: UE-V will create these user folders with the appropriate security.

segment.source: This permission configuration allows users to create folders for settings storage.
segment.target: This permission configuration allows users to create folders for settings storage.

segment.source: The UE-V agent creates and secures a settingspackage folder while running in the context of the user.
segment.target: The UE-V agent creates and secures a settingspackage folder while running in the context of the user.

segment.source: The user receives full control to their settingspackage folder.
segment.target: The user receives full control to their settingspackage folder.

segment.source: Other users do not inherit access to this folder.
segment.target: Other users do not inherit access to this folder.

segment.source: You do not need to create and secure individual user directories.
segment.target: You do not need to create and secure individual user directories.

segment.source: This will be done automatically by the agent that runs in the context of the user.
segment.target: This will be done automatically by the agent that runs in the context of the user.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Additional security can be configured when a Windows server is utilized for the settings storage share.
segment.target: Additional security can be configured when a Windows server is utilized for the settings storage share.

segment.source: UE-V can be configured to verify that either the local administrator's group or the current user is the owner of the folder where settings packages are stored.
segment.target: UE-V can be configured to verify that either the local administrator's group or the current user is the owner of the folder where settings packages are stored.

segment.source: To enable additional security use the following command:
segment.target: To enable additional security use the following command:

segment.source: Add a REGDWORD registry key named "RepositoryOwnerCheckEnabled" to .
segment.target: Add a REGDWORD registry key named "RepositoryOwnerCheckEnabled" to .

segment.source: Set registry key value to 1.
segment.target: Set registry key value to 1.

segment.source: When this configuration setting is in place, the UE-V agent verifies that the local administrator’s group or current user is the owner of the settingspackage folder.
segment.target: When this configuration setting is in place, the UE-V agent verifies that the local administrator’s group or current user is the owner of the settingspackage folder.

segment.source: If not, then the UE-V agent will not allow access to the folder.
segment.target: If not, then the UE-V agent will not allow access to the folder.

segment.source: If you must create folders for the users and ensure that you have the correct permissions set.
segment.target: If you must create folders for the users and ensure that you have the correct permissions set.

segment.source: We strongly recommend that you do not precreate folders and that instead, you allow the UE-V agent to create the folder for the user.
segment.target: We strongly recommend that you do not precreate folders and that instead, you allow the UE-V agent to create the folder for the user.

segment.source: Ensure that correct permissions are set when storing UE-V settings in a user’s home directory
segment.target: Ensure that correct permissions are set when storing UE-V settings in a user’s home directory

segment.source: If you redirect UE-V settings to a user’s home directory, be sure that the permissions on the user's home directory are set appropriately for your organization.
segment.target: If you redirect UE-V settings to a user’s home directory, be sure that the permissions on the user's home directory are set appropriately for your organization.
